reviewText:
This game, after watching a youtuber play it, seemed fun, so i got it.

I can't explain why, but its one of THOSE games that you become addicted to when you play it. The game presents itself as it is: You run a resturaunt (Seemingly alone with no other staff), you cook food, server it, earn money, buy new foods, repeat.

However, you have some things i myself have NEVER seen in resturant games before:

-You can cater to outside sources
-You can participate in a speical challange (Like the iron cheif in ORDER UP!)
-You have an e-mail system where you can get e-mails which can either help or hurt you (Also junk mail is sent)
-You can be robbed
You must keep up with chores (Washing dishes, taking out the trash, toilet maintenance, and setting rat traps) While also making sure you keep your customers happy

Now, all this CAN seem overwhelming, and it is at first, but once you get used to it and buy some upgrades (You can upgrade multiple things to help you, as well as upgrade your shop), it becomes just paying attetion. Not to mention, it contains FULL keyboard support, so while serving customers, you don't have to touch your mouse at all if you don't want to.

All in all, Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a truly unique game that i enjoy, and many other people would enjoy as well. It depends on your taste in games, but if you like unqiue games, you just HAVE to give this game a try.

reviewText: Really, really addicting arcade-y restaurant sim. There's upgrading and managing the menu between days to keep an attractive menu--not serving the same foods too often, keeping it decently healthy, and such--but the meat of the game is in trying to prepare foods for up to 8 customers at once before they lose patience and without screwing up any orders. It can be kind of slow to pick up if you're good at this kind of thing, since you're forced to wait for most upgrades to become available, but it gets to be quite an intense and fun game.\n\nThis is actually the third game in the series; you can download the second one (which is much the same but without menu management and with somewhat sloppy graphics) at http://www.vertigogaming.net/blog/?portfolio=ore-no-ryomi-1-2 for free to see what it's like.

reviewText: While appearing to be a food service simulator, Cook, Serve, Delicious feels more like a mini-game compilation in the vein of WarioWare. You are in charge of single-handed running the busiest restaurant in the world, and are expected to prepare and serve each meal promptly and to order. This is simple with cheaper dishes such as corn dogs and fish filet; however, as the game progresses, and you are asked to prepare more complicated meals, the pace mounts exponentially. Balancing your menu not only involved making sure you don't serve the same thing too often: it also involves balancing your menu so that you don't serve too many difficult dishes at once. For those not satisfied with the normal progression, random bets and Steam challenges are here to give you the opportunity to grab extra bragging rights.\n\nHonestly, CSD is one of the best cooking games I've played, and it's definitely worth the full $10.

reviewText: If you enjoy games such as Elite Beat Agents, Osu! Tatakae! Ouendan and its ilk, then you'll enjoy Cook, Serve, Delicious. Ultimately, it's a game about achieving perfection. You'll have PSCR PSCR PSCR engrained in your head as you learn how to cook Lasagna.\n\nThe game recently in late 2014 received a huge free update which introduced Battle Kitchen, allowing players to complete globally and see how they stack on the leaderboards. It's a great fun game which if you have your friends watch you play will make them think you're insane, but they just don't understand.

reviewText:
TL;DR - This is a QTE-based simulation that has as much to do about cooking as Game Dev Tycoon has to do about game development.  This can definitely be classed as a casual game, but the balance between grinding for the next 'star' for your restaurant is balanced by the new meal/equipment rewards.  The game lacks much depth, but is still very addictive and fun - I'd recommend to anyone who is after pick-up/put-down play that can be extended for hours without much additional effort.

Cooking is done by selecting the customer (1-9) and following through with the preset key-presses needed to cook the meal they requested ('k' for 'ketchup' etc) within the allocated time-slot; the more orders you complete perfectly, the greater your 'buzz' value, which, in turn, brings in more customers. While this system works pretty well, on recipes with a large number of potential ingredients you can end up encountering difficulties - Cabbage, Celery and Cinnamon can't ALL be bound to the letter 'C', so you can end up having some unintuitive combinations.

Beyond the time-management and, essentially, typing-speed - the only other depth to the game is in the money resource-management - which can be spent on either more recipes (each with their own pros/cons based on times-of-day and clientelle) and equipment (which gives passive bonuses - eg. need to do non-earning chores [such as cleaning the loo] as often).

My biggest complaint about this game is that it feels artificially long - it takes 20 days to earn your next 'star', even if all the other criteria has been met - making it sometimes feel like a bit of a grind if the unlocks you're earning each day are not for the recipes you're hoping for.  That said, the game does a good job of feeding you rewards often enough to keep you playing, and those days that you manage to get a perfect score do feel like a real achievement.

This is not the 'war and peace' or 'charles dickens' of gaming - it's a fun throwaway game that is more fun than you're probably expecting it to be.  Definitely recommended - particularly if Game Dev Tycoon ticked some of your boxes.

reviewText:
The Good: Kinda fun. Your hands will dash around the keyboard while you try to balance time and coordination.

The Bad: You really arent playing it for the animations/graphics but the grim faces of the hobos you serve are a bit of a downer.  There is also a decent chunk of mail to process every game day and the spam filter doesn't unlock for a while.

Final Thoughts: The achievements take a while to get rolling and you really have to commit to a lot of gameplay to get them all. Once you've clicked a mistake on someone's food there isnt a way to take it back! Threw too much pepper on that steak? Too bad. Cook it. Still, Im having fun.

reviewText:
This game, after watching a youtuber play it, seemed fun, so i got it.

I can't explain why, but its one of THOSE games that you become addicted to when you play it. The game presents itself as it is: You run a resturaunt (Seemingly alone with no other staff), you cook food, server it, earn money, buy new foods, repeat.

However, you have some things i myself have NEVER seen in resturant games before:

-You can cater to outside sources
-You can participate in a speical challange (Like the iron cheif in ORDER UP!)
-You have an e-mail system where you can get e-mails which can either help or hurt you (Also junk mail is sent)
-You can be robbed
You must keep up with chores (Washing dishes, taking out the trash, toilet maintenance, and setting rat traps) While also making sure you keep your customers happy

Now, all this CAN seem overwhelming, and it is at first, but once you get used to it and buy some upgrades (You can upgrade multiple things to help you, as well as upgrade your shop), it becomes just paying attetion. Not to mention, it contains FULL keyboard support, so while serving customers, you don't have to touch your mouse at all if you don't want to.

All in all, Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a truly unique game that i enjoy, and many other people would enjoy as well. It depends on your taste in games, but if you like unqiue games, you just HAVE to give this game a try.

reviewText:
50% recommend, 50% don't reccomend, but let me explain:

Cook, Serve, Delicious is absolutely a fun game.  But unfortunately it's not an original game.  I've played variations of this on 'free' flash based webgame sites for literally decades now.  It makes it a little hard to justify the price.  Now what it does, it does very well.  The action is faced paced and the graphics are very good.  But ultimately I keep coming back to the fact that this is essentially a 'diner' game much like I've played before.

So in the end, if that's the type of game you like, then you'll like this game a lot.  Just don't expect a whole lot of innovation.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: You get lots of orders at a time, only to find yourself under pressure to cook all of them exactly right and serve them in time. On top of that, there's (almost) always chores to make: doing the dishes, taking out the garbage, setting up rat traps... not that fancy, is it? And still, when you manage to do everything just fine, it feels SO satisfying! The game manages to keep that tension up most of the time, making you feel that you're just one step away from screwing up your combo -because, after all, you are-, and yet it always seems to be a manageable challenge. It's just exhilarating to get everything right!\n\nOn top of that, the atmosphere is sublime - the graphics are cute, and all the music and sounds fit together perfectly. There's nothing that feels out of place in here - the attention to detail is exquisite.

reviewText:
reposted from my tumblr:

Why CSD is my game of the year

CSD is one of those games that could be called Casual: The mechanics are easy to understand, yet the game manages to keep you busy and engaging, whilst allowing you to adjust the level of challenge in each consecutive playthrough. The way the gmae does this is by allowing you to decide that’s on the days many. The foods that need more prep and cooking allow you to earn more money, but because of the complexity of the preparation and making of the dish, it becomes more difficult to manage over the rush hour periods of the day.

Moreover the game even has some light management stuff going on for it: Each day you can change the menu you have to make it include less challenging foods, as well as replace menu items that have begun to rot (i.e. the foods have been on the menu for too long and customers aren’t interested in them). So with these days you might remove one complex menu item and replace it with another to keep yourself fresh in the eyes of customers.

There’s also the factor of safety insepctions, robberies as well as bets and stuff that’ll make the gameplay each day more or less hectic.

No IAP stuff

I like the fact that the game doesn’t make you buy some mooncredits in order to unlock speciality foods like coffee and stuff. No, all the things and all the foods can be aquired by being really clever and good with the menu items. This makes it a fair game, and this paragraph rather poorly written.

Should I play this game?

In my opinion yes. Even though it looks like a ‘casual’ game, there is a need for good finger dexterity and use of mouse if you are going to keep making wodnerful dishes and making your cutomers happy. There are NO DLC packages released, so you only pay 8.99 euros for the whole game. The game’s simple and easy to understand, and you might even get the cooking bug after playing this game!

Final grade:

If Mauve is considered to be unpleasant, and purple is the color of exhuberance, i am giving this game a STRONG BEIGE.

GOTY of 2013

reviewText: While appearing to be a food service simulator, Cook, Serve, Delicious feels more like a mini-game compilation in the vein of WarioWare. You are in charge of single-handed running the busiest restaurant in the world, and are expected to prepare and serve each meal promptly and to order. This is simple with cheaper dishes such as corn dogs and fish filet; however, as the game progresses, and you are asked to prepare more complicated meals, the pace mounts exponentially. Balancing your menu not only involved making sure you don't serve the same thing too often: it also involves balancing your menu so that you don't serve too many difficult dishes at once. For those not satisfied with the normal progression, random bets and Steam challenges are here to give you the opportunity to grab extra bragging rights.\n\nHonestly, CSD is one of the best cooking games I've played, and it's definitely worth the full $10.

This is actually a bit of a weird one. It's got all the makings of a bad game, what with repetiveness, little in the way of cosmetic upgrades, constant grinding and being very much a button mashing game. reviewText: I've been following this developer for years.  This game in particular went through several iterations early on, and has now grown into a delightfully polished and frenetic experience.  Things might seem calm as a no-star office building restaurant, but as your fame grows, the pace grows faster and faster; as the sole proprietor of the establishment, you've got quite the job on your hands, and it takes all your wits to keep your customers happy! Combine that with a great sense of humor (don't forget to read your e-mails!), wide variety of recipes (everything from soda to steak to stacked enchiladas), and challenges (watch out, Iron Cook!), and you've got a recipe for one delicious game.

reviewText:
This game captures the feel of working in a kitchen. With a controller, it's so much fun. The prep times, cook times and order of preparation are all perfectly balanced between the giant menu of potential food items to give the impression you are really preparing this food.

Even after many hours of play (on another account) and nearly perfecting my play of the game, it is still fun and challenging to go through an entire service without slipping up on at least one order. When you make it through a whole service without messing anything up it really feels like an achievement.

This is a great game to play with friends. Fun to watch and tough to master.

If you love food, cartoons and challenging video games then you will love this game. It's one of my all-time favorites.

reviewText:
This game, after watching a youtuber play it, seemed fun, so i got it.

I can't explain why, but its one of THOSE games that you become addicted to when you play it. The game presents itself as it is: You run a resturaunt (Seemingly alone with no other staff), you cook food, server it, earn money, buy new foods, repeat.

However, you have some things i myself have NEVER seen in resturant games before:

-You can cater to outside sources
-You can participate in a speical challange (Like the iron cheif in ORDER UP!)
-You have an e-mail system where you can get e-mails which can either help or hurt you (Also junk mail is sent)
-You can be robbed
You must keep up with chores (Washing dishes, taking out the trash, toilet maintenance, and setting rat traps) While also making sure you keep your customers happy

Now, all this CAN seem overwhelming, and it is at first, but once you get used to it and buy some upgrades (You can upgrade multiple things to help you, as well as upgrade your shop), it becomes just paying attetion. Not to mention, it contains FULL keyboard support, so while serving customers, you don't have to touch your mouse at all if you don't want to.

All in all, Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a truly unique game that i enjoy, and many other people would enjoy as well. It depends on your taste in games, but if you like unqiue games, you just HAVE to give this game a try.

reviewText: Very fun, hectic game that is sort of a mix between business building and quick-key action. You choose what is on your menu every day (with various foods having different effect on your 'daily buzz' aka your footfall) and during each day you prepare, cook and serve the food as requested by pressing quick-keys as fast as possible. There are also daily emails with bets, extra cash and funny little notes, upgrades to the kitchen and the food items, some mystery tickets and various levels of restaurant you climb your way up.\n\nNot much story here, but a lot of button-frantic fun.

reviewText:
I enjoyed playing Cook, Serve, Delicious for a couple of hours, after which it became a bit too repetitive for my tastes. Maybe I bought too much equipment too soon -- maybe I splurged on expensive food recipes. I'll never know!

It has a good moment-to-moment frenzy, without getting overly stressful or complicated. The graphics, while not dazzling, are charming in their own way, and the audio was nice enough too -- only tenderizing chicken elicited complaints from eavesdroppers (it requires repeating the same audio file 6 times, preventing me from winning any popularity contests).

In any event, I found myself having completed all of the goals for the first major progress marker (becoming a 2-star restaurant) on day 10, and had another 10 days to repeat before I could unlock the next set of challenges... alas. Maybe I'll get around to it, but... maybe not.

I hope more indie games explore cooking as a mechanic. It'd be excellent if Cook, Serve, Delicious were the beginning of a genre.

reviewText:
This restaurant simulator was one of the biggest surprises ever, at least for me. I've watched some videos of it, found it quite interesting and when I saw it was on sale on HumbleStore I picked it up and I most definitely do not regret it.

The core of the game is cooking. Customers will come to your establishment, they tell you what they want for food and you prepare it. You do that by pressing buttons that correspond with the ingredients the customers asked for. Say guy wants a hamburger with meat, cheese, tomatoes and pickles. To make that you press M,C,T,P. Sounds quite simple. However, there is a HUGE selection of foods and the cooking process varies drastically.

Some foods require you to put ingredients in specific order, some require cooking certain ingredients individually. Meat for hamburgers must be roasted first, similar thing with meat for nachos (there are 4 types of meat for nachos and 2 types of meat for hamburgers). To make pasta, you need to cook it first and then add the other ingredients etc etc. The variety is astounding and remembering all the buttons for all the ingredients is where this game is so challenging.

The buttons are usually the first letters of the ingredients but not always because some foods have loads of ingredientes, some of which start with the same letter. Pressing O for onions when onions are actually N and O is tomatoes because T is tomato sauce (that's pizza for you in this game) is where you will be doing most mistakes in the beginning. Also you can rebind all the buttons for all the foods individually, big thumbs up for that!

While the game can be very hard, it handles the difficulty very well. You start of with a few ingredients for each food and you can upgrade the foods (and buy new ones) with money you earn throughout the game. This will increase the price of the food but it will also usually make the food more complicated because it will give you additional ingredient(s) and more possible recipes. This way you will learn to prepare the food bit by bit, the game won't throw a lot of new stuff at you out of nowhere. There is also a practice mode for every food and you can even try to cook the food before you buy it so you know what you're getting. If you plan to finish the game though, you will need to learn pretty much all the foods anyway.

And that's how it goes, you build your menu and work for a day. After work you spend the money on stuff you need, pick new foods for your menu (or keep the old ones) and do another day. This routine is broken up by events like catering, where you prepare foods with a certain theme (snacks, italian food, drinks etc), bets (someone can bet you can't make 30 perfect orders while having pizza and icecream on your menu, for example. If you beat it, you get extra cash) and other events, most of which will require you to have specific foods on your menu (dating and VIP).

There is also a challenge mode with online leaderboards where you compete with other people online, you can play the campaign in local co-op where one person is expediting the orders and one is preparing them.

Overall, there is plenty of content in the game to keep you entertained for quite some time. Definitely pick it up if you see it on sale, but it's worth it even for a full price.

reviewText: Restaurant cooking simulator where you try to complete as many orders as you can, then spend your earnings on upgrades. I used an x360 controller to play. Cooking meals is somewhat like Cooking Mama, but here there's no gestures: you press a button/direction for a certain ingredient/action and almost all recipes are just inputting the right ingredients. You then cook it for a certain time and send it off before it gets burnt. A few early recipes just involve holding the down direction for a certain amount of time to fry the food, and a couple complex recipes require you to put the ingredients in a certain order. It's not too complex to learn (you start out with fewer ingredients/recipes until you upgrade the foods) but the biggest problem will be doing them fast enough so that your other orders don't suffer. I avoided upgrading certain foods to avoid the complexity. Upgraded wine can be pretty cost-effective if you don't like the complexity because it mostly requires mashing one button. Upgraded soup was my least favorite thing to do because of the sheer number of ingredients involved.\n\nCampaign mode is the big draw for me (earn upgrades, do events, read random e-mails), but there's also a nice multiplayer and challenge/score attack mode. Pretty fun if you like simulations or mastering sequences.

reviewText:
I'm sure everything I'm about to say about this game has probably been said before, but I'mma put my two cents in anyway.

Cook, Serve, Delicious is ostensibly a restaurant management game. In reality, it's something more like a rhythm game, especially when you get to the harder stages. You're put in charge of preparing and serving every dish and doing every chore and all of this is done by hotkeys (or controller buttons) - but watch out, 'cuz new tasks are constantly coming in and it's up to you to juggle them before the customers get impatient and leave. The better you do, the more popular your restaurant becomes and the more people come to eat there, which of course means more for you to do.

The one thing this game does well - very well, possibly better than any other game I've played - is inducing a flow state, which is to say once you get into the rhythm of handling tasks you'll be tapping away at keys like a madman and become completely oblivious to the world around you. There's no time to think, so don't: just learn the recipes off by heart and then let your instincts take over. I mean, just look at me: I play on Extreme Difficulty just because the normal difficulty is too damn slow and boring. I NEED THE RUSH. GIVE IT TO ME.

If you haven't already bought this game, please do: they're bringing out a CSD2 soon and I want it to be as fabulously spectacular as possible. Besides, don't *you* want to become so good at this game that your hands fly across the keyboard like a pair of tap-dancing spiders? Of course you do.

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious! is defitnely an amazing experience. It caught me for a lot of hours inside this restaurant ambient. In this game you're not only the one who cooks: you do literally everything. The restaurant management, the money control, the cleaning part, the kitchen part and lots of other stuff. And of course, you need to be as fast as possible to get a perfect service. This game gives you a lot of options on what you wanna cook, you make your own menu and give your restaurant your personality. Every time you level a star up the game gets harder and harder. You can count with a lot of challenges during your gameplay - that you can chose to do it or not. Full of special services, cooking games and even a co-op mode, Cook, Serve, Delicious! it's something you wanna get. May after awhile the cooking gets repetitive, but you can always fix that with changing your menu and what you're gonna serve to your costumers. It's a great simulator which makes you want to get all of the achievements and look foward to keep playing for many hours. And after beating it, it's not over. The game counts with a extra hard mode - like it wasn't already hard enough. If you want to get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, with pain in the arms and may even break your keyboard, but, with hours of fun, get that game right now!

reviewText:
I thought cooking was stressful in real life.

Don't let the cutesy pictures fool you—this game is the real deal. If you don't know your way around a keyboard, you're definitely going to struggle as you progress through the game.

I'm a couple in-game days and an Iron Cook win away from a 5-Star restaurant, and it's gotten to the point where I can only play a day or two in a single session before I'm so tense that I need to lie down. And yet, though it causes me extreme stress, this game is insanely fun. It's so satisfying to finish a day, and the feeling of accomplishment when you get a perfect day even with a robbery is awesome.

I definitely recommend this game if you enjoy a good challenge.

P.S. Soup is the worstttttt

reviewText:
An extremely well-polished polished game with simple but challenging gameplay. Each piece of food is a simple mini-puzzle, but as your restaurant gains popularity (and during rush-hours) you get allthe orders at once, which is great for inducing a feeling of flow and mastery if you nail them all, or feelings of you being *almost* good enough to do them perfectly.

The game gives you additional challenges to keep you always changing your menu and hence the mini-puzzles you're solving, and the game offers plenty of milestones and upgrades that always keep you wanting for the next upgrade for your kitchen.

While great for casual gaming, I played a solid 8 hrs after purchasing it. Would recommend.

reviewText:
So, I just finished getting the fabled 5 star rating on my restaurant, (currently going for the elusive Platinum Star) and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a challenge. Especially since it boosts your ability to multitask, (which definitely helps out with projects or assignments) and challenges your memory, accuracy, and speed. This game has really helped me multitask in many  different things, which I'd never expect from a video game.

What I Liked
The fact that it boosts your accuracy, speed, and multitasking skill.
The amount of gameplay put into the game, which is surprising for this kind of genre of games.
The true feeling of finally getting that last star for your restaurant, and just raking in the big money.
How fun the extra events and weekly challenges are.
What I Disliked
How hard some parts of the Iron Cook episodes are.
The slight unresponsiveness of a controller.
The fact you need a controller in order to play the game efficiently without any problems.
Overall, this game was a very fun time, and was definitely worth the $10 investment put into it. Considering this game still adds new things over time, even if it's not needed. If you want a challenge for once, try out Cook, Serve, Delicious!

reviewText:
This is actually a bit of a weird one. It's got all the makings of a bad game, what with repetiveness, little in the way of cosmetic upgrades, constant grinding and being very much a button mashing game. However, in spite of all this, the game is actually a very, very good game. There's just something about this game that keeps you wanting that extra slice and has you grilling for another go behind the counter.

The only criticism I actually have for this game at all is that multiplayer only works locally. Please. In this day and age where half your friends are at the very least in another country?

Nevertheless I'd definitely have bought this game, even if the price was doube what it is.

15/10 and I'll have fries to go.

reviewText:
I... I was not expecting to like this so much. Manage a restaurant by yourself. Pick your menu, prepare your food, prioritize your customers, do chores... etc. Practice multi-tasking and learning your food assembly by buttons on your controller. Played 3 days before writing this review.

Each day is composed of early morning and mid day luls, but there's lunch and dinner rushes. You must prepare each item on the menu by reading the customers order (burger assembly by buttons, cooking the meat patties), pouring beer by holding down left stick until the beer has a nice head on it, getting the right size soft drink cup (with or without ice), dunking the fries in the fryer until there's steam (with or without salt).... And chores! Set rat traps, flush the toilets (flush then sanitize your hands), scrub dishes, throw trash out (alternating buttons, the sanitize your hands).

Then at the end of the day, you can buy new items to serve, new equipment, and change around your menu.

And then repeat.

Buy it on sale. Buy it not on sale. It's good.

reviewText:
The Good: Kinda fun. Your hands will dash around the keyboard while you try to balance time and coordination.

The Bad: You really arent playing it for the animations/graphics but the grim faces of the hobos you serve are a bit of a downer.  There is also a decent chunk of mail to process every game day and the spam filter doesn't unlock for a while.

Final Thoughts: The achievements take a while to get rolling and you really have to commit to a lot of gameplay to get them all. Once you've clicked a mistake on someone's food there isnt a way to take it back! Threw too much pepper on that steak? Too bad. Cook it. Still, Im having fun.

reviewText:
The game is awesome, at the first look you can think it's just a browser game on Steam, but when you start playing it turns really addicting!
The game brings a big challenge, you need to serve your customers while you do simple chores like wash dishes and throw the trash out, and awkward chores like flushing the toilet (apaprently the customers can't do it) and fending off robbers.
Some recipes, you just need to press a key or two, but for others you need lots of ingredients, and every upgrade adds more ingredients, turning the game really challenging.
The game also have an enjoyable atmosphere, with good music and simple, but still pretty graphics.
The only bad things about the game are the low variety of recipe, the slow progression of stars, and we should be able to change our restaurant's appearence, it only changes when we get a new star.
The game is simple, but still addicting, great for fans of this kind of games, and have a good atmosphere for new players in this kind of game.
7.5/10

reviewText:
The most hardcore-Casual restraunt simulater there is!

Easy to pick up and fun to master controls (Gamepad or personally keyboard :3) with a vast amount of recipies you have to cook....FAST!

The game can be forgiving but also quite tough, you have to stay calm and keep on your toes, making perfect with practice  and planning accoringly putting you memory and fingers to the test.

Very addicting - Simular to pringles, you start one day but when you pop you cant stop :3
but very fun to play in short burts too if you have the control.

Can be very cheap and I definately recoment giving it a shot, not quite a typing teacher but definately a test of your cool and reactions!

reviewText: This is basically that kind of flash game about serving some sort of food and micro-managing the ingredients and cooking and stuff with little minigames (come on, you know the one)... except it's good. Like, really good. With surprisingly good gameplay and a side order of tongue-in-cheek humour, this game really stands out as something different, but still very welcome. If you wouldn't mind a fun, but simple time-waster to play now and then with some good jokes to keep you in high spirits the whole way then I would recommend this. It's no triple A title that will leave you thinking about its message after it's done, but it'll keep you smiling while it's still going. Well worth its quite modest price, despite its deceptive appearence.

reviewText: At first, I wasn't expecting much out of this game when I first laid my eyes on it, simply due to not being interested in these kinds of games in general. However, after getting this in a humble bundle, I gave it a shot and man is this a blast. It is literaly just a series of glorified quick-time event, but it's actually entertaining rather than in most other games that actually makes it annoying to go through. The goal of Cook, Serve, Delicious is work your way up from a zero star restaurant all the way up to a five star restaurant and is it very satisfiying to perfectly serve all of your customers at the end of the day. My only regret is that I wish I wasn't being such a cheapskate when paying for my humble bundle. Ah who am I kidding? I do this almost everytime I buy a game.

reviewText:
Welcome to Sherri Soda Tower, a run-down urban building with a...piece….of crap...space for you to build your….brand new thriving restaurant! No seriously, this game is awesome. Starting from scratch, your goal is to become a 5-star chef beginning with a dump of a restaurant, but it’s rent free! And no, you can’t hire any employees. Why would you do that? There’d be less money for you!

That’s right...you’ll not only cook all of the food you serve...but you’ll catch rats, throw out the garbage, wash the dishes, and even flush the toilet for the poor excuses of human beings that come through your restaurant! The good news is you take ALL THE TIPS HOME FOR YOURSELF!

On top of the mouth-watering art, and music that will make you wanna dance, this game is incredibly addictive and will leaving you wanting to finish one more day before you go to bed. It will test your reflexes and also provide numerous challenges. Just when you think you’ve mastered a food item, new recipes throw additional learning demands on you, while your customers lack the patience to put up with your ability to do things that truly only an octopus could do.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRvilDmb8nM
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious! is defitnely an amazing experience. It caught me for a lot of hours inside this restaurant ambient. In this game you're not only the one who cooks: you do literally everything. The restaurant management, the money control, the cleaning part, the kitchen part and lots of other stuff. And of course, you need to be as fast as possible to get a perfect service. This game gives you a lot of options on what you wanna cook, you make your own menu and give your restaurant your personality. Every time you level a star up the game gets harder and harder. You can count with a lot of challenges during your gameplay - that you can chose to do it or not. Full of special services, cooking games and even a co-op mode, Cook, Serve, Delicious! it's something you wanna get. May after awhile the cooking gets repetitive, but you can always fix that with changing your menu and what you're gonna serve to your costumers. It's a great simulator which makes you want to get all of the achievements and look foward to keep playing for many hours. And after beating it, it's not over. The game counts with a extra hard mode - like it wasn't already hard enough. If you want to get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, with pain in the arms and may even break your keyboard, but, with hours of fun, get that game right now!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I thought cooking was stressful in real life.

Don't let the cutesy pictures fool you—this game is the real deal. If you don't know your way around a keyboard, you're definitely going to struggle as you progress through the game.

I'm a couple in-game days and an Iron Cook win away from a 5-Star restaurant, and it's gotten to the point where I can only play a day or two in a single session before I'm so tense that I need to lie down. And yet, though it causes me extreme stress, this game is insanely fun. It's so satisfying to finish a day, and the feeling of accomplishment when you get a perfect day even with a robbery is awesome.

I definitely recommend this game if you enjoy a good challenge.

P.S. Soup is the worstttttt

reviewText:
I'm sure everything I'm about to say about this game has probably been said before, but I'mma put my two cents in anyway.

Cook, Serve, Delicious is ostensibly a restaurant management game. In reality, it's something more like a rhythm game, especially when you get to the harder stages. You're put in charge of preparing and serving every dish and doing every chore and all of this is done by hotkeys (or controller buttons) - but watch out, 'cuz new tasks are constantly coming in and it's up to you to juggle them before the customers get impatient and leave. The better you do, the more popular your restaurant becomes and the more people come to eat there, which of course means more for you to do.

The one thing this game does well - very well, possibly better than any other game I've played - is inducing a flow state, which is to say once you get into the rhythm of handling tasks you'll be tapping away at keys like a madman and become completely oblivious to the world around you. There's no time to think, so don't: just learn the recipes off by heart and then let your instincts take over. I mean, just look at me: I play on Extreme Difficulty just because the normal difficulty is too damn slow and boring. I NEED THE RUSH. GIVE IT TO ME.

If you haven't already bought this game, please do: they're bringing out a CSD2 soon and I want it to be as fabulously spectacular as possible. Besides, don't *you* want to become so good at this game that your hands fly across the keyboard like a pair of tap-dancing spiders? Of course you do.

reviewText:
It's a typing game about food. No, wait, it's a food game about typing.

It's Typing of the Dead without the zombies, but with more hamburgers, steaks, lobsters, and cilantro. OK, there's no cilantro. But there's anchovies. And when someone wants them on a pizza, you have to oblige no matter how much it hurts.

It's frantic. You're juggling multiple orders while new ones keep coming in in a roughshod attempt to get them all in perfect order. A maintained combo means better pay at the end of the day. Rewards await those who pull off the perfect day. Juggle a menu between highly complicated dishes with expensive prices and easier ones that don't quite make as much. Customize your menu to match the requirements for, and then beat the pants off of, the daily bet. Compete in Iron Che—I mean Cook. Iron Cook, yes—challenges. Grow from a meager hole-in-the-wall diner to a five star establishment, complete with whiny, needy celebrities to indulge!

Try to keep up. You won't. You'll try, but you won't. And then, one day, you will. It will be glorious. And all the while you'll have one hell of a time.

reviewText: So there's basically 3 different categories of food games: waitress (Diner Dash), line cook (assembling orders) and management (you run the resturaunt, hire and fire etc). This game is a combination of a line cook and a management game. It's pretty fast pace and it has multiple side challenges. You play as a line cook who also has to keep up with chores while completeing orders. It sounds overwhelming, and at first it is but eventually you adapt to the gameplay. It's smooth, the graphics fit the game right and I literally feel like this is me running a little food shop by myself. Very fun, 4 hours went by damn quick. I highly recommend, especially if you enjoy food games

reviewText: This is a great game. Totally a fun way to kill some time. You work as a chef in a resturant. You also flush toilets and catch rats. Why? Because you can that's why. Or you can ignore the nastiness that's going on behind the scenes, continue to serve up food and get a poorer rating at the end of the day. It works on a daily basis with upgrades for the food you serve, the restruant, the equipment etc. The sound effects are adorable, and I love the art style. My only complaint would be that I would like more artwork of the people, but it's not really a complaint seeing as this game is amazingly well done and polished. Upgrade your shop, trap all them rats because screw PETA and button mash your way to the top of the resturant. 9/10

reviewText: If you want to play a restaurant sim, this is the best game for the genre. CSD is an incredibly deep and meaty (pun intended) experience. Unlike other restaurant sims, this is played behind the counter, rather than an overhead restaurant view, making the game more immersive. Along with buying foods for your restaurant, you'll be upgrading them and adding more ingredients. There is also catering for office parties, cooking in an iron chef parody, and an intense version of the normal game wer you must perfect all orders or walk home in shame. Along with those, you can date people by cooking their favorite foods and take up bets to make a lot of cash. Overall, CSD is a very deep game that'll have you playing for hours.

reviewText: This is a time management restaurant sim. What makes it different is the level of depth. Its pretty straightforward as far as the cooking part. Up to 4 people come in and ask for items, and you create it by hitting a selection of keys. IE if someone orders a corn dog, you hit the number displaying that person's request, the dog appears on screen and then you can put ketchup or mustard on it by hitting K or M or both depending on what the person wants. There are complicated items as well, like soups which require many items, chopping and cooking. That part is pretty self explanatory and theres a turorial at the beginning to explain it.\n\nIt gets really hectic though, because each person will only wait for a limited amount of time for you to start preparing their order or they go away angry. There is a rush hour" at certain times of the day where all 4 slots fill up fast and are constantly full. I havent found a way to keep everyone happy yet

reviewText:
Simply put, it is, in my opinion, one of the most frantic game you can experience - and a keyboard game at that.
The action is non-stop, though you can carefully take it up, one step at a time, thanks to the games upgrade system and its generosity in allowing you to tailor the experience you want to get out of it.
I strongly advise you do not judge it based on videos or screenshots but give the demo, available on the web, a try : you will know very quickly if this is the game for you.
Vertigogaming's games were long dued on Steam. The Steam version isn't just a quick and dirty port, but features the proper overlay, achievements and cloud support.

I give it 5 pizzas out of 2 baked potatoes.

If you enjoy it, I advise you check out the equally brilliant The Oil Blue from the same author on Greenlight.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Make sure not to overplay the game.

I have to say that this game is both great and bad. Firstly, I enjoyed it a lot. There was a decent amount of difficulty to it in the beginning but it was also very fun to get into, setting up your menu and everything.

This game has now taken hold as my most-played in terms of time, though I do have to say that it sat up idle for almost 12 hours one day, so technically Just Cause 2 is the most still.

I liked the idea much more than games where you run a person around a restaurant, and I thought its execution was great. The graphics and sounds are well-done. I loved the emails you get along the way. And the food and features were all pretty interesting to try out and use.

The only problem I had with the game was that it just took too long to get to the end, in that having 20 days per star was repetitive. I was fine with the extra events and all of the requirements to beat the game, but the main issue was that I would always finish all of the objectives relatively soon and the Finish 20 days" objective would always be the last thing I had to do.

From there
date: it would always be a boring repetitive run from like 10 to 20 days. I would shake up my menu and try some things
recommended: but it eventually got boring. Even though I still played the game a ton
hoursPlayed: I ended up doing it on and off as a timekiller whenever I reached the point where I needed to get to 20 days.\n\nSimilarly

I had to grind away for that.

The main way I think the game could be improved is simply to add more items to the menu (and increase the rate of food upgrades) and also maybe add a few more improvements to the restaurant.

While the game was still fun

reviewText:
Should be called Cook, Scream, Delicious! Because this game will frustrate you. The only thing missing from this game is buying your own groceries.

The first play through is very fun, although it can be repetitive you end up changing your menu due to buying new foods, or the weather, or just getting as much buzz as possible. At around 3 or 4 stars, you end up using the same menu. The bets really help change that up, as well as VIPs and dating.

The second playthrough, on extreme difficulty, on the other hand could be better. At first, yes it is intense, its hard, but messing up doesn't matter anymore. Making money? You will have tonnes. You will end up making only the easiest foods (fish, chicken, beer, etc.) just so you can get those last few achievements. Lets face it, it gets boring because you get accustomed to it and the star level requirements are exactly the same as on normal. It would be much more difficult and extreme" as you put it if the requirements to get to the next star was different. Perhaps a buzz % requirement instead

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious is a button masher cooking game well suited for people liking casual games. It gives you a nice experience of fighting against the clock to serve all you customers. The only negative aspect of the game is the amount of time that is needed to get to the next level. It does become a bit of a grindfest to get to a 5 star restaurant. But from the other side, it will give you an incentive to keep on playing.\n\nThe gameplay felt refreshing as I didnt see this implementation of using other keys on your keyboard than the regular awsd in a lot of games. You can also choose to use your mouse, but after a few cooking days you will want to switch to using your keys.

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious! by Veritgo Games is a frantic simulation of living the day-to-day life of an up-and-coming sole restaurant owner and operator. While the game may appear to be a simple casual game in a sea of other restaurant managing sims predominantly on mobile platforms, Cook, Serve, Delicious! distinguishes itself by being extremely fast-paced as a chain of frantic Warioware-style mini-games. CSD requires plenty of concentration and muscle memory in order for players to adequately serve their customers.\n\nOne point of contention which I rarely see mentioned in reviews for this game is the potentially controversial choice of having players control an alleged murderer and cannibal throughout the course of the game. While not initially revealed, players who take care in reading all of the messages in their email inbox at the beginning of each day are able to piece together the truth to the game's story and find out about all of the people the protagonist has murdered and is trying to dispose of by processing them into delicious delicacies for the enjoyment of the customers of SherriSoda Tower. I feel that is a bit of an odd narrative choice and found it to be a bit unnecessary, but I am happy to report that this revelation did not make the food I was preparing seem any less delicious and did not detract from the enjoyment I had when I finished a hard day's work with a stable of satisfied customers.

reviewText: This fast paced marvel is on my favorites list. It looked intersting to start with, and it just sucked me in more and more. I kinda just want to stay at a certain level. I like to hone my skills with the keyboard memorization and such. Most people will look at this  game and think its foolish and pointless in a sense. I actually think this game is a skill tester. I also think it could be helpful for kids. When in school, I had a special class that was literally to help me memorize where all the keys were, how to put my hands in a proper position that gave me the utmost advantage with hand cordination. It has truly helped me and this game reminds me alot of that exercise. It makes you remember certain patterns and orders and ingredients. Its also a recipe zone, so if you plan to be a cook in the future, you can get a small hint of cooking knowledge from this. I definetly recommend this to people who like challenges and are good/bad at hand-eye cordination. I also give it a 8/10 :)

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious is a button masher cooking game well suited for people liking casual games. It gives you a nice experience of fighting against the clock to serve all you customers. The only negative aspect of the game is the amount of time that is needed to get to the next level. It does become a bit of a grindfest to get to a 5 star restaurant. reviewText:
Should be called Cook, Scream, Delicious! Because this game will frustrate you. The only thing missing from this game is buying your own groceries.

The first play through is very fun, although it can be repetitive you end up changing your menu due to buying new foods, or the weather, or just getting as much buzz as possible. At around 3 or 4 stars, you end up using the same menu. The bets really help change that up, as well as VIPs and dating.

The second playthrough, on extreme difficulty, on the other hand could be better. At first, yes it is intense, its hard, but messing up doesn't matter anymore. Making money? You will have tonnes. You will end up making only the easiest foods (fish, chicken, beer, etc.) just so you can get those last few achievements. Lets face it, it gets boring because you get accustomed to it and the star level requirements are exactly the same as on normal. reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Make sure not to overplay the game.

I have to say that this game is both great and bad. Firstly, I enjoyed it a lot. There was a decent amount of difficulty to it in the beginning but it was also very fun to get into, setting up your menu and everything.

This game has now taken hold as my most-played in terms of time, though I do have to say that it sat up idle for almost 12 hours one day, so technically Just Cause 2 is the most still.

I liked the idea much more than games where you run a person around a restaurant, and I thought its execution was great. The graphics and sounds are well-done. I loved the emails you get along the way. And the food and features were all pretty interesting to try out and use.

The only problem I had with the game was that it just took too long to get to the end, in that having 20 days per star was repetitive. I was fine with the extra events and all of the requirements to beat the game, but the main issue was that I would always finish all of the objectives relatively soon and the Finish 20 days" objective would always be the last thing I had to do.

From there
date: it would always be a boring repetitive run from like 10 to 20 days. I would shake up my menu and try some things
recommended: but it eventually got boring. Even though I still played the game a ton
hoursPlayed: I ended up doing it on and off as a timekiller whenever I reached the point where I needed to get to 20 days.\n\nSimilarly
voteText: I got to the end of the game with everything from the store and Silver/Platinum Stars. Then I carried over into Extreme Difficulty
helpfulPercent: but I got everything else there relatively quickly. It wasn't super easy
votesHelpful: but it was more than manageable. Then I was stuck just finishing off 15
votesTotal: 000 customers when I had completed everything else at 10
votesFunny: 000 or so. Thus
commentsCount:
I had to grind away for that.

The main way I think the game could be improved is simply to add more items to the menu (and increase the rate of food upgrades) and also maybe add a few more improvements to the restaurant.

While the game was still fun

reviewText: Cook, Serve, Delicious! by Veritgo Games is a frantic simulation of living the day-to-day life of an up-and-coming sole restaurant owner and operator. While the game may appear to be a simple casual game in a sea of other restaurant managing sims predominantly on mobile platforms, Cook, Serve, Delicious! distinguishes itself by being extremely fast-paced as a chain of frantic Warioware-style mini-games. CSD requires plenty of concentration and muscle memory in order for players to adequately serve their customers.\n\nOne point of contention which I rarely see mentioned in reviews for this game is the potentially controversial choice of having players control an alleged murderer and cannibal throughout the course of the game. While not initially revealed, players who take care in reading all of the messages in their email inbox at the beginning of each day are able to piece together the truth to the game's story and find out about all of the people the protagonist has murdered and is trying to dispose of by processing them into delicious delicacies for the enjoyment of the customers of SherriSoda Tower. I feel that is a bit of an odd narrative choice and found it to be a bit unnecessary, but I am happy to report that this revelation did not make the food I was preparing seem any less delicious and did not detract from the enjoyment I had when I finished a hard day's work with a stable of satisfied customers.

reviewText: This is honestly one of the most fun and interesting games I've played in a while. So many little things come together to make it feel fantastic. The aesthetic design is great. The visuals are interesting and varied without being overwhelming, and the sound effects when preparing food make it so satisfying. The soundtrack is also great, and it perfectly fits the tone of the game. There's jazz, funk, samba, all sorts of styles, and all of them can be either driving or relaxing.The game is also well balanced, which may seem like a weird thing to say, but there was never one setup that I knew I could coast through the whole game with. The game makes you change up your menu and buy and upgrade your foods to make it more varied and challenging. And boy, does it get challenging. But it never punishes you for some bs reason. If you get punished, it's because you made a mistake. And since you can arrange your own menu, you only make it as difficult as you want to. Most of the time, anyways. This game is so fantastic, and I cannot praise it highly enough. It may be one of my favorite games. You may not have the same experience as I did, but I would still highly reccommend that you at least try out this game. At $10, it's a great buy.

reviewText:
I never thought a cooking game could be so damn good and challenging!
At first, the game is pretty easy, with simple recipes to help you get used to it, but later on it becomes a typing madness!
The drawings are charming, the music is superb and the gameplay is perfect: it's addicting, not too repetitive and the difficulty can easily be changed thanks to the variety of recipes and the difficulty on each dish.
If you are looking to test your memory and reaction skills, this is the game for you!
But if you are looking for some humour or great art, this is ALSO the game for you!

reviewText:
Original Review:

Too much d*mn reading involved.   If you want action and don't want to be bothered reading every little thing it shoves down your throat, look elsewhere.


2nd Chance Review:

Okay, so after giving it some thought, I decided to give this game a 2nd chance.  I felt I may have been a tad too hasty in negatively rating this game after being enraged by the bombardment of text in the tutorial.  At the time, I only had 2 achievements.  I now have all 52 achievements.

This game isn't as bad as I thought.  It provides a nice challange and provides a nice time waster.


Pros:

Nice music
Great meals  (With many recipes to keep you occupied)
Great challenges
Amusing Spam E-mails (I leave the spam filter off)


Cons:

Can be a tad repetitive (You can change up your menu, but after a while, you may get bored of the mechanics)
Cumbersome tutorial (Bombards you with text when you just want to jump in and figure it out for yourself.  I feel it's best to figure this one out without a tutorial)


I know, I've had a change of heart, but I recommend this title.  It helps you organize tasks, organize priorities, and understand the basics of operations Management.

8/10

reviewText:
I don't know if putting the establishment on the top floor of an office building is such a good idea.   You seem to be open seven days a week with no free time, your customers are picky as hell, and any prospective love interest just uses you for your cooking and abandons you for more interesting pursuits even if you do everything right.

And what kind of platinum-star restaurant only does takeout and doesn't have any staff other than the owner?

But seriously, very entertaining game (if you aren't afraid of using the keyboard, anyway) and big thumbs up to the developers to expand on the game (extreme difficulty, battle kitchen, etc) without charging players for a DLC.  Kudos to all of you.

Bananas Foster/10

reviewText:
Cook, Serve, Delicious is a fast-paced game, where you run your own restaurant. The gameplay is centered around cooking and serving food in segments that consist of one game day, which last for around 7 minutes. Inbetween these days you manage your menu, upgrade your restaurant and buy new, increasingly complex recipes.
The game's theme and aesthetics might suggest this to be an easy, casual experience. This is not true. Cooking each meal is a process requiring multiple ingredients to be added in a rapid sequence to keep the customers from waiting too long. Adding ingredients happens by pressing the releated hotkey (fully rebindable). Some of the more complicated foods require specific ingredients to be added either in an order, multiple times, or within a time limit. The game's difficulty comes from this fact, as during the rush hour, which happens twice a day, you'll really be in a hurry to fulfil the many requests by your customers. And if you don't serve them fast enough, the customers will leave with an empty stomach, lowering your hype.
The hype mechanic adjusts game difficulty based on your skill level - more hype leads to more customers. If you successfully serve customers, more shall arrive next day, making the game more taxing and complicated for the player. This naturally leads to more income, allowing you to advance through upgrades more quickly. And as you gain more hype and even more complicated recipes, even the fastest of keyboard users and multitaskers will find him or herself challenged during a rush hour.
In between days you'll be able to redesign your menu. Different foods have different perks and disadvantages. For example, pizza will increase your hype during evenings when people come in for a late dinner, but if combined with other greasy foods on the menu, will detract from hype due to health nuts turning up their noses at your fatty-filled menus. Some foods also suffer from menu decay"
date: which makes them lower hype if left on the menu for too many days in a row. This adds a light strategy element to the game
recommended: as you'll be balancing different foods for different occasions and days
hoursPlayed: trying to find the perfect combinations.\nCook
voteText: Serve
helpfulPercent: Delicious! also has a few side activities in form of catering for example. These missions require you to cook and serve specific dishes under strict conditions. Completing these activities grant you extra cash
votesHelpful: but due to them requiring to own the recipes used during the mission
votesTotal: might end up being a drain instead of a boost for your cash.\nOverall the game offers a surprisingly difficult
votesFunny: yet highly statisfying piece of enterntaiment that can be enjoyed in short bursts of 10-20 minutes. The hype system cleverly balances game difficulty with your skill level
commentsCount: and buying and upgrading recipes makes increases complexity and challenge at a smooth rate. Definitely recommended."

reviewText: Love it! It's very engaging and challenging, keeping your fingertips moving at all times. I haven't played a game with a learning curve this smooth in so long, it makes me wonder why more people haven't heard of this game. There are tons of upgrades and different types of food/equipment items to choose from that will effect how your restaurant flourish. Start from the dirt and make your way up to the fabulous 5-star extravaganza. It is a really satisfying type of experience that I can hardly put down myself. Definitely check this one out, even if you think you wouldn't like a cooking/prep game!\n\nJust to add some sprinkles to the cake; Imagine if Typing of the Dead and Wario Ware had a baby that went on to grow up and marry Cooking Mama, and then both of them had a baby. To follow, that baby grew up and went to a Culinary Arts School where (s)he succeeded better than both his grandparents and parents. That baby is this game in a nutshell.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have a real thing for games that involve typing (like Typing of the Dead... and not much else), so this game is basically the game form of crack for me.
It's a great mix of restaurant management sim, and crazy hectic typing game. The game goes through a cycle of start a new day, serve customers, earn money, then at the end of the day you spend that money on new foods and upgrades, ready for the next day. This makes it very hard to put down, always want to move on to the next day.
The difficulty can be overwhelming when you start out, but you quickly learn patterns for the food and feel like a serving machine! The cloud saves mean I can continue my game on the macbook or windows pc, which is good.
A very fun game. Highly recommended.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: CSD is far more fun and enthralling than it has any right being. You work to assemble food by using keystrokes, against the clock... which in itself sounds like a pretty banal premise. But by adding menu management, food upgrades and equipment, it gives just enough of a sense of progression that addiction sets in. Just as I've spent many a night playing 4X games saying just one more turn
date: this one can easily become just one more day." Several hours later..."

reviewText: I bought Cook, Serve, Delicious! wanting a kitchen management game, and I certainly got what I asked for! It's got a very nice visual appeal, and the gameplay is very fast. Unfortunately, I myself am not quite so perfect a match for the game. As soon as rush hour hits, I go into a panic and lose my ability to read the orders for a few seconds! But that said, I love the game. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes cooking or kitchen management games.

reviewText:
Back during the Autumn Sale, I was browsing through the vast catalog of games, and came several titles of games, that were drastically cut down in price. Among these games, included blockbuster titles like Payday 2, Saints Row 4, Arma 3, yet, though I chose to buy a few cheaper games (you know, more bang for your buck). At checkout, I ended up purchasing 3 games, one in which was called Cook, Serve, Delicious.

From the store page, the game appears very similar to diner dash; an indie/arcade game, also focused on the food business. The screenshots were pretty interesting, as well as the description. However, without too background knowledge, (being none of my friends owned this game, and there was no available demo), I blindly started playing the game, and immediately loved the game. Like any games, I immediately pointed out the pros and cons, and here they are.

Pros: The game has a large portion of menu options".  100+ hours of gameplay (depending on if you do side activities or not).  Provides a realistic aspect of the food business
date: by allowing gamers to have to change around the menu
recommended: in order to gain a higher "daily buzz" rating.  Detailed textures for both the food and the restaraunt.\n\nCons: Game takes to long to level up.   There are a few noticeable glitches (with the Coffee menu item active
hoursPlayed: trying to use the mouse to select the item
voteText: does not work).\n\nGraphics - For this style of game
helpfulPercent: it is definitely well detailed.  Anti-aliasing works well
votesHelpful: without creating too much extra stress on your system.\n\nSounds - I could do without the elavator music as background music
votesTotal: for this game.   Some of the sounds for the menu items being cooked
votesFunny: sound pretty rediculous. Then again
commentsCount: some of them sound really realistic.\n\nOverall - I would suggest this game. Being the game is at an already low price

reviewText:
I adore this game!  It's often the last thing I do before bed and the first thing I start after breakfast.  I've played a lot of cooking and restaurant games, and this is the best by far.

As Starcraft players already know, using the keyboard instead of the mouse makes a huge difference in playing speed.  It's a lot of fun to memorize the sequences of preparation and see how fast you can go.  Unfortunatley, in a relatively short period of time,  I've run out of new food types to purchase.  Hope there are expansion plans in the future...

reviewText:
This game is extremely addictive! It might look like a very simple game but believe me, it's quite hard. There are some annoyances with re-mapping keybinds (some actions can't be re-mapped at all). My tip is not to be afraid of re-mapping keys if the game gets too hard at a certain point. The music and sounds aren't the best but it's not what made me play for hours and hours on. I can't really tell what keeps me going on playing the game. Perhaps to challenge myself? It's a great casual game for people who still want a little challenge and reaction time training! You will have to work up some awesome reflexes and you might even surprise yourself how fast you can be!

Oh and chores. You will have to do chores. A lot of them. Do them as fast as you can so you won't fall behind in service! The key is to continue to bind keys so that you can do everything faster. Every second counts!

It's a restaurant management game and I have to mention that it's not very forgiving. It keeps you wanting/needing to strive for success and it will take a long time to master this game. You will be able to buy new food and equipment then upgrade them, you have to controll your positive and negative buzz, you'll get more and more customers the more you advance into the game. You can take bets and do different events that requires you to not mess up or you'll fail. You can even date people and stop robberies! But all of that comes with a price! Gaining money in the game is hard and purchases/upgrades are not cheap. There are a LOT of achievements to get, but don't think you'll be able to faceroll through the game to get them. You actually have to work for them.

Your restaurants rank up (stars) when you've completed a number of requirements. This gives you a new restaurant, more prep stations and unlocks more food, events, upgrades and equipment.

The graphics are pretty nice, I like the visuals of the game. But as I said, the music isn't much to cheer for, I turned it off after an hour or so.

Want to challenge yourself? Get this game!

reviewText: Although many hardcore" gamers would discount this as a mobile game ported to PC - and a stupid one - I think it deserves some credit.\n\nCSD certainly won't teach you how to cook
date: but it holds value as a mental workout. Succeeding at this game requires memorization - both muscle memory and traditional - in addition to being able to quickly read onscreen instructions and translate them into keyboard shortcuts in order to properly fill the customer orders.\n\nEach "food" or menu item
recommended: once upgraded all the way (for absurd amounts of money) individually holds the potential for dozens of "recipe" possibilities. In addition to this you maintain a menu of 6 of these items and have to be able to do any of them at any given time. This will exercise your mind and your fingers.\n\nThe game also features extra challenges
hoursPlayed: some of which are mandatory to complete story mode
voteText: that further accentuate the mental exercises presented normally in the game. Overall
helpfulPercent: you must also manage your restaurant's menu in order to generate "buzz"
votesHelpful: thus increasing your popularity and daily income.\n\nWhile it's not a hardcore restaurant simulator
votesTotal: it's still a good way to stay focused when you wake up on the weekend and can't think straight yet."

reviewText:
As the Chef of Cook Serve Delicious, it was hard rising up through the ranks of food, my manager screaming at me to put tomato sauce on raw dough, customers refusing to throw money on the table, no, they had to have some mother effing tip jar, and to make matters worse, when i actually gave them the right food they still stomped off ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off because their god damn beer wasn't foamy enough. Or maybe the fact that i couldn't just throw empty cups at people for them to serve themselves their own soft drinks! I mean why?! Are you crippled? Apparently they are, tipless sons of beaches.

But you know what.. I was fine with all of that... Until I realized I was missing ingredients and had to click the effing SPACEBAR! I mean why?! There's enough room on the beginning keybinding page to NOT have to press SPacebar. So as my customers refused to throw their tips at me, I had to figure out that the reason they were stomping off pissier then a bunch of somalian pirates forced to listen to Brittany Spears at seaside as they run away from her strange wavern roars is because half the friggen ingrediants were missing from my point of vision and guess what? Nothing led me to see, hey, there's an image over here to click over to ANOTHER friggen page of conveluded bull ♥♥♥♥ that I didn't even know about.

So on my last day of work, both my manager and I threw beer mugs, uncooked chicken, raw potatos, and pizza dough at people then screamed YOU'RE FAT ENOUGH as we threw lettuce at them for their Bull ♥♥♥♥ salads. And... They friggen liked it!

My god! We worked so hard with so many pissy people for so long that when we started throwing crappy food at them they started to like it! It's like Stockholm syndrome for restraunts!

Life lesson of the day, just throw raw dough at people, they'll get the messege, if not, start firing the raw chicken at them.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgsrmQeGA0Q

This si more of a QTE game rather than anything else. It's masked as a restaurant management and simulation, but trust me, that's not what this game is. The tags for this game are badly thought out. You DO get to run a restaurant, and choose what food it serves and get money but the thing is... you don't sit back and watch OTHERS serve the actual food. YOU have to do it.

So you end up doing the dishes, and putting meat and stuff on a hamburger and so on. On a timer. That's the entire actual gameplay.

So, while I do think it's an okay game, I was mislead. I thought it was a REAL management sim.

reviewText: I thought this game would be more focused on managing a store, akin to a Tycoon game. Instead, it's a very repetitive game where you just click ingredients in a certain order to make food, over and over again. There are very little ways you can control the growth of your restaurant, and the few ways available mostly just allow you to click different ingredients in a different order.\n\nThe game is very cheap (I got it for $1 on a Steam sale), but still, not recommended.

reviewText:
I'm torn on this game.
On one side, I really enjoy it, as you need to be fast, have good memory and be able to multi-task.
On the other hand, I thought this would be more of a macro restaurant management than what I experienced so far. I only played a couple of hours, but it's starting to get tedious.
I'll keep playing, maybe it will grow on me when I get more hours in.

reviewText: The interface is crude.  It is not well made like the Flipline (Papa's) franchise.  The most practical approach is to use a keyboard/mouse combinative input, where the optimal approach changes for every task.  Default configuration is M for mustard on a corndog, but it is Y on another dish because M represents something else.  It would be best to use the keyboard for everything as it's so much faster, but having to use the arrow keys along with the rest of the keyboard makes it quite unatural to play as a typing game.\n\nI think the food items' bonuses and maluses are well planned, and conceptionally the game is fine, but the implementation is very lacking.

reviewText:
The game is artifically padded with having to complete 100 days to beat the game. Many of the items have too many choices to perfectly do during rush hour, so using food items that are simply made like chicken and steak in order to complete perfect days for bonuses really limits gameplay. If you want to use complicated items, using the mouse is too difficult as it requires too many clicks. You have to memorize the order names along with all of the keyboard binds to be successful and that is tedious. Rebinding the keys of each item to the left hand would alleviate that problem, but that should've been an option from the start.

More like Click, Type, Headache!

reviewText:
Overly complex for what it is and steals the fun away.

The premise is you select items to cook, and as you advance you can buy equipment to cook more advanced items.

The main problem is the interface for things like the pizza. You have to tab to a second page for ingredients.
There's some ridiculous items like wine, where you have to tap like mad to open a cork, and some stupidly easy ones like the corndog where you hit one of two choices. The game suffers from a clunky interface.

Beyond that, it's just about memorization and how good your typing skills are, and the layers of overcomplexity
kill the fun.
